subject: Re: [junit] Junit4 new features ?
msgSnippet: Roger, Good questions. 1) I would be interested in seeing the patch.  It strikes me as something that could be done with a custom runner, without patching
messageBody:
Roger,

Good questions.

1) I would be interested in seeing the patch. It strikes me as
something that could be done with a custom runner, without patching
JUnit: have you found that to be true?

2) I've heard of wanting to only instantiate a test class once (you
can do that in JUnit, see
http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/19159). Is that what
you're looking for, or is there another advantage in having non-static
@BeforeClass, etc?

3) As I understand it, dependsOnMethods allows one test method to be
skipped if another one fails. I had a version of this in my own JUnit
sandbox for a while, and found it not as useful as I'd liked. If used
to truly say "this test, valid on its own, will fail if this other
test, valid on its own, fails", I found that the dependencies became
stale, and tests ended up skipped that I wanted to run. However,
there were two situations in which it was useful:

a) In some other cases, I found I was using the method dependency as a
way of specifying preconditions for a test case. This meant that I
needed a test that stated, for example, whether the test database was
up, or whether I was connected to the Internet, or whether I felt like
clicking on some buttons to help test the UI. In JUnit 4.4, these
kinds of dependencies are now marked by assumptions:

@Test public void parseGoogleCorrectly() {
assumeTrue(internetConnected());
//...
}

I might decide that if the internet is not connected, my tests should
fail, in which case I can test the condition directly:

@Test public void internetShouldBeConnected() {
assertTrue(internetConnected());
}

b) Dependencies between tests can be useful in initial TDD
development: I write a test A, and find out that I've bitten off more
than I can chew. I write a test B for a smaller chunk of
functionality, and make A dependent on B, so that I can ignore A until
B passes. However, I found that these dependencies cluttered the
code, and weren't much help once initial development was done. I
actually made the dependency method deprecated, so that I remembered
to remove the dependencies once everything was working.

My guess is that using assumptions will handle most reasons that
people use dependsOnMethod. If you do find the temporary dependency
scaffolding from 3b interesting, let's talk more about it.

Thanks,

David Saff
